q3.value:
The cross-race effect is the tendency for individuals to better recognize same rather than other race faces. Several prominent theoretical perspectives on the cross-race effect posit that the phenomenon occurs, in part, because the ingroup is inherently more motivationally relevant than the outgroup, due to rewards, relationships, etc. (i.e., individuals are internally motivated to attend to ingroup members).  
The purpose of this experiment is to examine the influence of competing motivations on the cross-race effect. Specifically, we seek to discover how the cross-race effect is affected when internal and external motivations are congruent or in competition with one another. We will experimentally “manipulate” one internal motivation: race (i.e., participants will either be self-identified Black or White people) as a proxy for motivation to attend to the ingroup.  We will experimentally manipulate one external motivation: financial incentive (i.e., participants will be offered additional compensation for accurately responding to either Black or White people). And we will measure one internal motivation: Social Dominance Orientation (i.e., the belief that some groups are superior to others, and that it is good for superior groups to dominate inferior groups).

q4.value:
1.	We predict a cross-race effect (i.e., better recognition for ingroup versus outgroup members) when no external motivation is present.

2.	We predict that the cross-race effect will be largest (relative to no external / competing motivation conditions) when participants are offered additional compensation for accurate recall of same race faces (i.e., motivation to attend to ingroup is congruent with financial motivation). 

3.	We predict that the cross-race effect will be attenuated when participants are offered additional compensation for accurate recall of other race faces (i.e., motivation to attend to ingroup competes with financial motivation). Whether the cross-race effect disappears completely, or is diminished (relative to no external / congruent motivation conditions), or is moderated by race (e.g., diminished among White participants, disappears among Black participants) is an open question.

4.	We predict that social dominance orientation (SDO) will interact with participant race to moderate the cross-race effect. To the extent that higher status groups are more motivationally relevant than lower status groups to high-SDO participants, they should better recognize White (i.e., normatively higher status) than Black (i.e., normatively lower status) faces. Consequently, we predict a positive relationship between SDO and the cross-race effect among White participants (i.e., high-SDO White participants show a larger ingroup recognition advantage), but a negative relationship between SDO and the cross-race effect among Black participants (i.e., high-SDO Black participants will show a smaller ingroup recognition advantage). Whether SDO also interacts with motivation condition (or motivation x participant race) remains an open question. For example, an internal motivation (i.e., SDO) should be more chronically salient than an external one (i.e., financial incentive), so financial motivations might only influence low-SDO participants.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
This experiment consists of a 2 (stimuli race: Black, White – within-participants) x 2 (participant race: Black, White --- between-participants) x 3 (incentive condition: Black accuracy, White accuracy, No external motivation – between-participants) mixed design.  

This experiment will consist of a memory task which involves a learning phase, filler task, and recognition phase. In the learning phase, participants will passively view 36 White female and 36 Black female faces one at a time, in a random order and for two seconds each. As a filler task, participants will then complete the SDO Scale. Finally, in the recognition phase, participants will view faces from the learning phase, along with 36 novel White female and 36 novel Black female faces. Each image will be paired with the question, “Have you seen this face before?,” to which the participant answers “yes” or “no”. Participants’ race/ethnicity will be collected among other demographics at the end of the study. A manipulation and attention check will also be included in the demographics section.
Before beginning the memory task, participants will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions in which external motivation is manipulated. In the Black accuracy condition, participants will be instructed to pay close attention to the Black faces in the memory task, and that the top 3 participants who respond most accurately to Black faces will earn an additional $30, $20, and $10, respectively. The White accuracy condition will largely be identical to the Black accuracy condition, except that participants will be instructed to pay close attention to the White faces, and that the top 3 participants who respond most accurately to White faces will earn additional compensation. Participants in the No external motivation condition will be instructed to pay attention to all faces, with no mention of additional compensation.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to incentive conditions. Stimulus race is a within-participants variable, and participant race is not assignable.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit only self-reported Black and White participants through Turk Prime. 

Due to Turk Prime’s screening restrictions, we cannot exclude a priori self-identified Black or White biracials. Consequently, we will exclude post hoc, but before analysis, participants who do not self-identify only as Black or White. Additionally, we will exclude from final analysis participants with incomplete data, as well as participants who respond incorrectly to attention and manipulation check items:
Attention Check
“If you are reading this, please select "Three" from the options below.”
o	One
o	Two
o	Three
o	Four
Manipulation Check
"I tried to remember the [African or European] American faces more." Is this statement true or false for you?” 
o	True
o	False
(item will not be shown to participants in the no external motivation condition)

q13.value: Based on power analysis of pre-test data, we will collect 100 participants per experimental condition, with a total sample size of 600 – 300 Black and 300 White participants.

question.value:
-	Financial incentive condition (for Black face accuracy, for White face accuracy, none)
-	Stimuli race (Black or White)

-	Participant race
-	Social Dominance Orientation
-	Correct “yes” recognition responses to stimuli that were presented at learning (i.e., a “Hit”)
-	Incorrect “yes” recognition responses to stimuli that were not presented at learning (i.e., a “False Alarm”)
o	“Hits” and “False Alarms” for Black and White stimuli will be transformed, separately, into estimates of memory strength (d’) and response bias (c) according to Signal Detection Theory
o	“Hits” and “False Alarms” for Black and White stimuli will be transformed, separately, into estimates of memory strength (d’) and response bias (c) according to Signal Detection Theory

We will run a 2 (stimuli race: Black, White – within-participants) x 2 (participant race: Black, White --- between-participants) x 3 (incentive condition: Black accuracy, White accuracy, No external motivation – between-participants) mixed model ANOVA to predict memory strength for White versus Black stimuli and, separately, response bias for White versus Black stimuli. Assuming the ANOVA is significant, we will conduct follow-up linear contrasts to test hypotheses 1-3. Additionally, we will run a multiple regression to test hypothesis 4.

q21.value: We will make statistical inferences based on p-values and effect sizes according to standard conventions, i.e., p<.05, Cohen's d according to Cohen's 1992 recommendations.

q22.value:
Due to Turk Prime’s screening restrictions, we cannot exclude a priori self-identified Black or White biracials. Consequently, we will exclude post hoc, but before analysis, participants who do not self-identify only as Black or White. Additionally, we will exclude from final analysis participants with incomplete data, as well as participants who respond incorrectly to attention and manipulation check items:
Attention Check
“If you are reading this, please select "Three" from the options below.”
o	One
o	Two
o	Three
o	Four
Manipulation Check
"I tried to remember the [African or European] American faces more." Is this statement true or false for you?” 
o	True
o	False
(item will not be shown to participants in the no external motivation condition)

attributes.title: Social category label effect on the perception of ethnic groups: case of Albanians and Romani people

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Changing the labels: how using the neutral or derogatory term impacts the social perceptions of Romani

other.value:
In the case of insignificant results, we will merge two databases (one from this study and the other from the previous) into one and perform Bayesian analyses to compare the null hypothesis to the alternative. 
We will also check whether the pattern changes when only ethnic Serbian participants are included compared to the case when only Romani participants are excluded (i.e. all other ethnicities are included).

sample.value: Based on the mediation effect with small and large size of the paths (α = .14, β = .59; Fritz & MacKinnon, 2007), we aim at 400 participants. Therefore,  we will stop collecting after 450 responses, to ensure enough valid responses after the exclusions.

analyses.value: MANOVA with the condition as the independent variable (derogatory/neutral term) and perceptions of warmth, competence, morality, and social distance as dependent variables. Significant MANOVA will be followed with separate ANOVAs. Also, we will test whether ideology moderates these effects. Next, we will perform the factor analysis (FA) on potential mediators (income, education, occupation and reputation). If FA shows one-factor solution, we will perform mediation analysis (conditional mediation analyses in case of the significant moderation effect) with factor scores as a mediator. We will also perform mediation analyses with each of the mediators.

outliers.value: We will exclude the participants who fail the attention check question, speeders (less than 60 seconds) or multivariate outliers (based on Mahalanobis distance). Participants of non-Serbian ethnicity will also be excluded.

dependent.value:
1.	Perceptions of warmth, competence and morality (Leach, Ellemers, & Barreto, 2007)
2.	Social distance (adjusted from Dietrich et al., 2004). Participants indicate willingness (1 = not willing at all to 5 = definitely willing) to have a member of this group as a flatmate, friend, colleague, boyfriend/girlfriend, and spouse.
3.  Mediators: Perceived status (income, education, occupation and reputation)

conditions.value: Two conditions. In the first condition, the ethnic group is referred to using the derogatory term (“Cigani”), while in the second condition they are referred to using the neutral term (“Romi”). Both groups fill out the same measures of social perception.

hypothesis.value: In the first study, we found that the Romani ethnic group is perceived as warmer and more competent when the neutral term is used compared to the derogatory one, in the Serbian social context. We also found that ideology moderated the effect so that right-wing participants were more susceptible to the effect. The aim of the second study is to replicate these findings and investigate the potential mediating role of the group’s perceived social status.

3.  Mediators: Perceived status (income, education, occupation and reputation)

We also found that ideology moderated the effect so that right-wing participants were more susceptible to the effect. The aim of the second study is to replicate these findings and investigate the potential mediating role of the group’s perceived social status.

attributes.title: The effect of feedbackhistory on over- and underconfidence

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: The effect of feedbackhistory on over- and underconfidence

sample.value: We will open up 40 slots. If this leaves us with less than 30 datasets (i.e., no-shows, exclusions, etc.) we will continue data collection until 30 participants are tested.

analyses.value:
For the main analysis, we will calculate average confidence as a function coherence and condition. Model simulations predict higher average confidence in the 90% vs the 70% feedback condition, and effect that is more pronounced at lower coherence values. 
Second, we will calculate metacognitive accuracy to examine metacognitive insight, seperately for the two feedback conditions. Simulations predict higher metacognitive insight in the 70% compared to the 90% feedback condition.

In addition, we will look at how RTs and accuracy vary as a function of block and coherence.

outliers.value: Participants who perform at chance level during the test phase will be excluded from the data. Trials on which RTs differ 2.5 SD from the average (calculated seperately for participant) will be excluded.

dependent.value: The dependent variables are the accuracy, response time and reported confidence on the random dot motion task.

conditions.value: The experiment will be 4x2 fully within-subject design. There will be 4 coherence levels (.05, .1, .2 or .4) and 2 orientation axes (horizontal vs vertical random dot movement). During the training phase seperate blocks will be about horizontal or vertical decisions, and within each block the amount of feedback will differ depending on the orientation axis. Feedback will be presented on 50% of the trials. When in a horizontal discrimination block , 90% of the feedback will be about correct trials. When in a vertical discrimination block , 70% of feedback will be about correct trials (counterbalanced between participants). In the test phase, the same design will be used but no more feedback is provided.

hypothesis.value:
Hypothesis 1: People who receive a high proportion of positive feedback during a training phase, will report a higher level of confidence about their answers in a subsequent test phase, compared to people who receive a lower proportion of positive feedback. To study this question, participants will perform a random dot motion task. During the training phase, they will receive 90% vs 70% feedback about correct trials. In the test phase, feedback is ommitted. During both training and test phase participants provide confidence ratings about the accuracy of their decision.

Hypothesis 2: People will make a better estimation of their accuracy (i.e., higher metacognitive accuracy) when in the 70% compared to the 90% condition.

When in a vertical discrimination block , 70% of feedback will be about correct trials (counterbalanced between participants). In the test phase, the same design will be used but no more feedback is provided.

Hypothesis 1: People who receive a high proportion of positive feedback during a training phase, will report a higher level of confidence about their answers in a subsequent test phase, compared to people who receive a lower proportion of positive feedback. To study this question, participants will perform a random dot motion task. During the training phase, they will receive 90% vs 70% feedback about correct trials. data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Two manipulation check items are included: (7-point agree/disagree scale)
•	I felt like I had control over the horse race ticket I received.
•	I felt like I was in control of the risks I took.
A t-test will test whether the average of these two measures differ between the low- and high perceived autonomy conditions.

An exploratory analysis will examine whether gender moderates the 2(perceived autonomy) x 2(risk level) interaction on preference rating (with women showing a larger interaction than men.)

analyses.value: OLS regression predicting ratings from perceived autonomy (binary indicator), risk level (binary indicator) and their interaction.  The regression will include control variables of age (7-point scale, centered ), education (5-point scale, centered), race (white vs. other), and gender (binary).

outliers.value:
MTurk Restrictions: 
- 99% approval rate
- US only

dependent.value: Ratings on the question: “I am happy with the horse I am betting on.” (7-point agree/disagree scale)

conditions.value:
•	Low perceived autonomy, low risk:
Imagine that you are at the Kentucky Derby.  You were randomly given a ticket that pays out if Horse 5 places first.  The odds when the wager was placed was that Horse 5 would win with a 99.99% chance.  The value of the wager placed was $0.01.  Hence, you have a 99.99% chance of winning $0.01.
•	Low perceived autonomy, high risk:
Imagine that you are at the Kentucky Derby.  You were randomly given a ticket that pays out if Horse 5 places first.  The odds when the wager was placed was that Horse 5 would win with a 1% chance.  The value of the wager placed was $1.00.  Hence,  you have a 1% chance of winning $1.00.
•	High perceived autonomy, low risk:
Imagine that you are at the Kentucky Derby.  You have been given a choice between two tickets that pay out if the specified horse places first.  The odds when the wagers were placed differ between the two tickets as do the value of the two wagers. Which of these two tickets do you want to receive?
o	Horse 5: you have a 99.99% chance of winning $0.01.   [Almost all should choose this.]
o	Horse 7: you have a 1% chance of winning $0.01.
•	High perceived autonomy, high risk:
Imagine that you are at the Kentucky Derby.  You have been given a choice between two tickets that pay out if the specified horse places first.  The odds when the wagers were placed differ between the two tickets as do the value of the two wagers. Which of these two tickets do you want to receive?
o	Horse 5: you have a 1% chance of winning $1.00.   [Almost all should choose this.]
o	Horse 7: you have a 1% chance of winning $0.01.

hypothesis.value: Under low perceived autonomy (control condition), participants will rate a highly certain option as preferable to a high risk lottery with the same EV. In contrast, under high perceived autonomy (bogus choice condition), participants will rate the high risk lottery as similar to the highly certain option.

•	High perceived autonomy, high risk:
Imagine that you are at the Kentucky Derby.  You have been given a choice between two tickets that pay out if the specified horse places first.  The odds when the wagers were placed differ between the two tickets as do the value of the two wagers. Which of these two tickets do you want to receive?
o	Horse 5: you have a 1% chance of winning $1.00.   [Almost all should choose this.]
o	Horse 7: you have a 1% chance of winning $0.01.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Under low perceived autonomy (control condition), participants will rate a highly certain option as preferable to a high risk lottery with the same EV. In contrast, under high perceived autonomy (bogus choice condition), participants will rate the high risk lottery as similar to the highly certain option.

summary.value: Do people react warmly to smiling or non-smiling faces?

registration_responses.summary: Do people react warmly to smiling or non-smiling faces?

attributes.title: Success Drivers of Natural Resources Management: A Conjoint Experiment On Groundwater Management in Brazil

q1.value: Success Drivers of Natural Resources Management: A Conjoint Experiment On Groundwater Management in Brazil

q2.value: Alicia Cooperman | Alexandra Richey | Brigitte Seim

q5.value: We are grateful to the EGAP Metaketa III: Natural Resources initiative for generous research support and Aline Martins and Andre Assumpcao for excellent research assistance.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Studies suggest that carefully designed common-pool resource management programs can improve water security; for example, Elinor Ostrom (1990) identified key features of self-governed institutions, the resource, and its appropriators that increase the likelihood of self-governance of scarce resources. However, many NGO and government policies do not have the ability to address all-important features at once. In addition, users’ perception of management systems is important to increase buy-in and adoption of a new program.

q16.value: The goal of the conjoint experiment is to comparatively evaluate the individual drivers of natural resources conservation behavior and the community-level determinants of successful natural resources management systems. Specifically, we test five possible drivers, with ten corresponding hypotheses: five in which the outcome variable is individual water conservation; and five in which the outcome variable is community-level water security. Hypothesis 1: Community discussion regarding the water resource leads to greater individual water conservation. Hypothesis 2: Community discussion regarding the water resource leads to greater community-level water security. Hypothesis 3: Community sanctions for over-use of water lead to greater individual water conservation. Hypothesis 4: Community sanctions for over-use of water lead to greater community-level water security. Hypothesis 5: Formal water use rules and penalties lead to greater individual water conservation. Hypothesis 6: Formal water use rules and penalties lead to greater community-level water security. Hypothesis 7: Payment for water use leads to greater individual water conservation. Hypothesis 8: Payment for water use leads to greater community-level water security. Hypothesis 9: Monitoring and dissemination of water resource conditions to users leads to greater individual water conservation. Hypothesis 10: Monitoring and dissemination of water resource conditions to users leads to greater community-level water security.

q17.value: We conducted a conjoint survey experiment about groundwater management with rural residents (n=1949) in the semi-arid region of Northeast Brazil. We conduct a conjoint experiment on natural resources governance success factors embedded in a survey conducted in Ceará, Brazil. The baseline survey is part of the EGAP Metaketa III: Natural Resources initiative. The pre-analysis plan for our project associated with this metaketa can be found here: http://egap.org/registration/4480 A conjoint experiment is a tool initially used in marketing research to compare features of a product against one another, and we adapt this technique to the topic and context by creating pictogram booklets with five varying features of a natural resources management system: 1) discussion among community members regarding the water resource (high/low), 2) community sanctions for over-use of water (yes/no), 3) formal water use rules and penalties (both/only rules/neither), 4) payment for water use (yes/no), 5) monitoring and dissemination of water resource conditions to users (yes/no). See pre-analysis plan for additional detail on profiles and outcome questions.

summary.value:
This project contains supplementary files for the paper titled: Innovative strategies to fight antimicrobial resistance: crowdsourcing to expand medical training. 
These include Delphi Survey and results, clinical cases and score, judging criteria and promotional banners/flyers.
